posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: Being concerned with privacy, Iâ€™m sure both the folks at Signal and a good portion of users are familiar with tor, the dark web browser. Other privacy-centered messaging services have a .onion address, and even Facebook have one, so why doesnâ€™t Signal? Iâ€™m sure that with a dark web address and a pgp signature linked in the download page, many folks who are more cautious would download the app.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Why is using the normal website over Tor not good enough as it is?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: Websites outside of the tor cloud are vulnerable to correlation attacks even via tor, which means an attacker could figure out and log which websites youâ€™re logging to, making access via tor no more private than a regular HTTPS connection. Making a .onion address solves that problem, and may therefore be more attractive to privacy-minded users.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: I doubt anyone will be trialed for visiting signal.org, even if they live under an opressive regime. Ok maybe in North Korea? But they donâ€™t have access to the regular internet anyway I guess.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
We already have several countries whose ISPs block Signal. It is not inconceivable that even with the great protection that tor provides regularly, a user could face danger for trying to access Signal.
The fact that even Facebook, the company that absolutely does not care about its users, realised the benefits of having a .onion address, says quite a lot about why signal should have one as well.

en.wikipedia.org

Facebook onion address

Pages for logged out editors learn more The Facebook onion address located at facebookwkhpilnemxj7asaniu7vnjjbiltxjqhye3mhbshg7kx5tfyd.onion (formerly facebookcorewwwi.onion) is a site that allows access to Facebook through the Tor protocol, using its .onion top-level domain. Prior to the release of an official .onion domain, accessing Facebook through Tor would sometimes lead to error messages and inability to access the website. ProPublica explicitly referenced the existence of Fac...

Talya (she/her):

We already have several countries whose ISPs block Signal. It is not inconceivable that even with the great protection that tor provides regularly, a user could face danger for trying to access Signal.

If theyâ€™re going to face danger for just visiting the website, then they would face even more danger from actually using the app, which is not something an .onion address would solve.

Talya (she/her):

The fact that even Facebook, the company that absolutely does not care about its users, realised the benefits of having a .onion address, says quite a lot about why signal should have one as well.

As you seem to acknowledge, Facebook clearly did it to benefit themselves, so why would that mean anything for Signal?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Now that Twitter has joined in on the party, itâ€™s getting really embarrassing that Signal is not part of the large and ever growing group of services that offer .onion access.
Thereâ€™s several security benefits to an .onion address, as well as it generally being more friendly towards tor (i.e. more privacy-minded) users (especially when using the special toolbox the tor community offers for .onion integration).
I mean, when the head of WhatsApp endorses the integration, you know itâ€™s time. Letâ€™s get Signal a .onion address!

link_counts.title: Twitter Launches Tor Onion Service Making Site Easier to Access in Russia
real-world-onion-sites/README.md at master Â· alecmuffett/real-world-onion-sites Â· GitHub
Why offer an Onion Address rather than just encourage browsing-over-Tor? â€“ dropsafe

posts.cooked: Signal tends to follow popular trends (see upcoming Stories in Signal for example, and the apps use a WhatsApp user agent for link previews) and it is most similar to WhatsApp, and so do not expect to see anything until WhatsApp gets a onion link.

posts.name: mls
posts.cooked: It is not so easy. Just having an onion address would not work as Tor does not support UDP protocols, but only TCP.

posts.name: Altonss
posts.cooked: I think we are just talking about the website, which is not so hard

posts.name: Harold Finch
posts.cooked: Having a mirror on the onion network has not only a practical technical value in countries where the Signal URL is blocked, but also a great political value towards a safer Internet. Thanks to the mirrors of: Twitter, Facebook, BBC, The Guardianâ€¦ everyone has realised that the Tor network is not a â€˜Darkâ€™ network. I hope https://molly.im and https://signal.org will have an .onion mirror

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: Signal recently had to deal with the Signal website being blocked in Iran, which is yet another thing having a .onion address would have been helpful for. Signal and Tor are both in the privacy and censorship-breaking business, so having a .onion address for signal is only natural.

posts.name: ã‚½ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚¢ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ»ã‚ªãƒ³ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ³
posts.cooked: With the change in the American government, it would be important to ensure that thereâ€™s an uncensored way to access the Signal website. This is one of the ways to do that and I was surprised when I did not find a way to access Signal via an onion address.

posts.name: lucasmz
posts.cooked:
Not that I donâ€™t agree here, it does seem off to not have an onion address, but I think itâ€™s worthy to note these are anonymity/censorship-resistance tools, not necessarily privacy. Signal canâ€™t be considered anonymous, its usage requires phone numbers (which are tied to identities in most of the world) and users arenâ€™t enforced to use anonymizing networks. Signal is, though, pretty amazing with privacy and security, everything is wrapped in E2EE, while other solutions donâ€™t do that, and rely solely on anonymizing networks and the care of the user. (Signalâ€™s extense E2EE does give some anonymity in some contexts, but probably not enough for someone thatâ€™s using Tor)

Facebook and X may have Tor addresses, but they also enforce a bunch of human verification, theyâ€™re only trying to pass blocks (and probably just to spread more nazi propaganda), not be anonymous
